Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant met the 1095-day physical presence requirement in Canada for citizenship
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed to have met residency requirement but destroyed expired passport after alleged advice from CIC officer
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of citizenship application denial
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet statutory residency requirement
Assessment_Factor: Credibility of evidence regarding physical presence
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under the Federal Courts Act
Credibility_Assessment: Judge found no credible proof of residency due to lack of documentation
Legal_Provision_Cited: Requirement of 1095 days of physical presence in Canada over four years
Application_Basis: Citizenship application based on claimed residency
Evidence_Assessed: Insufficient evidence of physical presence in Canada
Governing_Rule: Applicant must accumulate 1095 days of physical presence in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Destruction of expired passport led to inability to verify presence
Cause_Description: Applicant failed to provide sufficient evidence of meeting residency requirement
Evidence_Handling: Passport destroyed upon alleged advice from immigration officer
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of Citizenship Act regarding 1095-day physical presence requirement
Evidence_Issues: Lack of verifiable documents to prove residency
Evidence_Assessment: Judge applied 'physical presence' test correctly; insufficient evidence provided
Decision_Rationale: Decision was reasonable based on absence of credible evidence
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Federal Court
Evidentiary_Issues: Destroyed passport; reliance on unverified personal testimony
